_exec_summary.SummaryText:
In response to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), this Process Safety Management / Risk Management Program (PSM/RMP) has been developed for the Ruprecht Company facility located in Mundelein, IL.  This document has been prepared to satisfy the following:



Federal EPA's, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r), Program 3 requirements.



Please note that references made throughout this document in the form of "Ruprecht Company" and "Ruprecht" refer only to the Ruprecht Company facility located in Mundelein, IL.



The purpose of this document is to:



?X    Increase the protection of public health, the environment, and facility employees by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.



?X    Assist Ruprecht Company and local government agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling regulated substances.



This document addresses Ruprecht Company administrative and operational programs to prevent regulated substance-related accidents and reduce potential risks.  The regulated substances of concern and focus of this document is ammonia.  Ammonia is used to provide refrigeration for warehouse cold storage.





ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Ruprecht Company facility has an emergency response plan in effect.  The Emergency Response Plan (Plan) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1.)    To save lives.

2.)    To minimize and avoid injuries.

3.)    To protect the environment.

4.)    To minimize property damage.



Ruprecht Company maintains a safety committee whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the re

sponse organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year.  This Plan will be reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The ammonia refrigeration system uses roughly 13,000 pounds of ammonia for processing and warehouse cold storage.  The majority of the system is located in the engine room including vessels and compressors.  The condenser is mounted on the engine room roof, and all of the evaporators are located in their respective cold storage rooms/process areas.



The refrigeration cycle begins with the transfer of high pressure liquid ammonia from the High Pressure Receiver to the High Temperature Pump Receiver and Low Temperature Pump Receiver which pumps the liquid to the evaporators throughout the facility.  The liquid ammonia expands as it enters the various evaporator coils, reducing the temperature.  These evaporators are used to maintain low air temperatures for warehouse/dock storage.  As the air is chilled by the evaporators, the ammonia is vaporized and returned to the respective pump receivers.



The compressors pull the low pressure ammonia vapor from the pump receivers where it is compressed into a high pressure vapor.  This vapor is then piped to the condenser, where the ammonia is converted back to high pressure liquid and recycled to the High Pressure Receiver.  The auto purger periodically purges the system of non-condensables collected in the HPR and the condensers.
